title: Inconsistent/Wrong error messages
body_html:
1. should be "but got Tensor"
  2. should be consistent to 1
import torch
from torch.autograd import Variable

torch.cat([Variable(torch.Tensor(2,3)),torch.Tensor(2,3)],0)

RuntimeError: expected Variable as element 1 in argument 0, but got list

torch.cat([torch.Tensor(2,3),Variable(torch.Tensor(2,3)).cuda()],0)

TypeError: cat received an invalid combination of arguments - got (list, int), but expected one of:
 * (sequence[torch.FloatTensor] seq)
 * (sequence[torch.FloatTensor] seq, int dim)
      didn't match because some of the arguments have invalid types: (list, int)
  • OS: Linux
  • PyTorch version: 0.3.1
  • How you installed PyTorch (conda, pip, source): pip under anaconda
  • Python version: 2.7
  • CUDA/cuDNN version: 9.0
body_text:
should be "but got Tensor"
should be consistent to 1

import torch
from torch.autograd import Variable

torch.cat([Variable(torch.Tensor(2,3)),torch.Tensor(2,3)],0)

RuntimeError: expected Variable as element 1 in argument 0, but got list

torch.cat([torch.Tensor(2,3),Variable(torch.Tensor(2,3)).cuda()],0)

TypeError: cat received an invalid combination of arguments - got (list, int), but expected one of:
 * (sequence[torch.FloatTensor] seq)
 * (sequence[torch.FloatTensor] seq, int dim)
      didn't match because some of the arguments have invalid types: (list, int)

OS: Linux
PyTorch version: 0.3.1
How you installed PyTorch (conda, pip, source): pip under anaconda
Python version: 2.7
CUDA/cuDNN version: 9.0
body:
1. should be "but got Tensor"
2. should be consistent to 1

```python
import torch
from torch.autograd import Variable

torch.cat([Variable(torch.Tensor(2,3)),torch.Tensor(2,3)],0)

RuntimeError: expected Variable as element 1 in argument 0, but got list

torch.cat([torch.Tensor(2,3),Variable(torch.Tensor(2,3)).cuda()],0)

TypeError: cat received an invalid combination of arguments - got (list, int), but expected one of:
 * (sequence[torch.FloatTensor] seq)
 * (sequence[torch.FloatTensor] seq, int dim)
      didn't match because some of the arguments have invalid types: (list, int)
```

- OS: Linux
- PyTorch version: 0.3.1
- How you installed PyTorch (conda, pip, source): pip under anaconda
- Python version: 2.7
- CUDA/cuDNN version: 9.0
